recipe.title: Steak & Eggs  with Quick Kimchi Fried Rice
recipe.description: When steak and eggs join forces, the result is a deeply satisfying meal for any time of day. The classic duo appears across different cuisines—each with its own delicious additions. Here, we’re serving up our seared steaks and fried eggs Korean-style, with a side of kimchi fried rice. The fried rice gets a kick of heat from two traditional ingredients: gochujang (a red chile paste), and gochugaru (red chile flakes) in the marinade for the zesty, crunchy kimchi.

stories.title: Jasmine Rice
stories.description: Originally from Thailand, jasmine rice is a long grain variety named for its buttery, floral aroma. First cultivated exclusively for royalty, it cooks up to a soft, white, fluffy consistency and makes a perfect, fragrant accompaniment to many dishes.

stories.title: Green Cabbage
stories.description: This hearty leafy green is perhaps the most versatile and popular type of cabbage. It’s known for its densely packed head and pale green leaves, which can be enjoyed raw or cooked. When raw, the leaves have a slightly peppery flavor (they are often thinly sliced and used in slaws and salads). Cooked, they develop a pleasant sweetness, and are ideal for stir-fries, soups or braising.

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

stories.title: Sesame Oil
stories.description: This intensely aromatic ingredient is made from the essential oils found in sesame seeds. Though it may sound like a pretty simple process, it's really anything but. Sesame seeds can only be pressed into oil when they're ripe, and finding bunches of ripe seeds is no easy task. The seeds ripen at different times, and most sesame farmers still cut them by hand to ensure a good crop. Once the seeds are ripe, the incredibly flavorful oil is extracted and filtered, creating the product we recognize and love.

stories.title: Gochujang
stories.description: Considered by many to be the backbone of Korean cuisine, this red chile paste can be used in everything from marinades and sauces to soups and stews. Its concentrated flavor means a little goes a long way in adding a kick of heat and depth of flavor to a recipe. It’s made from a base of fermented soybean paste and glutinous rice, to which red chile pepper powder, salt and other aromatics are added, resulting in its rich red color and powerful heat.

stories.title: Rice Vinegar
stories.description: A pillar of Asian cooking, rice vinegar is slightly milder than regular (or grape) vinegar. Its aftertaste is also faintly sweet. Rice vinegar is made by soaking rice in water, then straining out the rice and boiling the water with sugar. Yeast is added, and the mixture is allowed to ferment. It's great for pickling and using in sweet-and-sour recipes. It's also essential for making sushi rice.

ingredients.description: Kimchi Spice Blend (Gochugaru, Granulated Sugar, Garlic Powder, Ground Ginger, Black Sesame Seeds & White Sesame Seeds)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 1 Tablespoon Kimchi Spice Blend (Gochugaru, Granulated Sugar, Garlic Powder, Ground Ginger, Black Sesame Seeds & White Sesame Seeds)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Tablespoon Kimchi Spice Blend (Gochugaru, Granulated Sugar, Garlic Powder, Ground Ginger, Black Sesame Seeds & White Sesame Seeds)

stories.title: Kimchi Spice Blend
stories.description:
This spice blend packs powerful Korean flavor. Gochugaru, a smoky, pleasantly robust Korean chile powder, garlic powder and ground ginger are balanced by a sweet touch of granulated sugar. We’ve also added gorgeous black and white sesame seeds for a mildly nutty crunch.

4 Parts Gochugaru

2 Parts Granulated Sugar

1 Part Black Sesame Seeds

1 Part White Sesame Seeds

1 Part Garlic Powder

1 Part Ground Ginger

recipe_steps.step_text: While the rice continues to cook, in a large bowl, combine the cabbage, vinegar, white bottoms of the scallions and as much of the spice blend as you’d like, depending on how spicy you’d like the dish to be. Drizzle with olive oil and toss to thoroughly coat; season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside to marinate, stirring occasionally, for at least 10 minutes.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: To the pan of reserved fond, add the sesame oil and as much of the gochujang as you’d like, depending on how spicy you’d like the dish to be. Cook on medium-high, stirring occasionally, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant. Add the cooked rice and cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until thoroughly combined. Add the kimchi; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until thoroughly combined; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide between 2 plates and set aside in a warm place. Rinse and wipe out the pan.

In the pan used to finish the rice, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium until hot. Crack the eggs into the pan, keeping them separate; season with salt and pepper. Cook 1 to 3 minutes, or until the whites are set and the yolks are cooked to your desired degree of doneness. Remove from heat. Find the lines of muscle (or grain) of the rested steaks; thinly slice against the grain. Divide the sliced steaks and fried eggs between the plates of finished rice. Garnish with the green tops of the scallions. Enjoy!

stories.title: How to Slice Beef Against the Grain
stories.description: As you probably have noticed, cows are enormous. So their muscles need to be incredibly strong just to move around their bodies. These hard-working muscles are made up of groups of long fibers that are laid out parallel to each other. If you look closely at a steak or roast, you can see the “grain,” or the alignment, of these fibers. Because they are designed to be strong, the fibers that make up the grain can be tough to chew if left whole. Slicing perpendicular to the grain cuts the fibers short, creating tender, succulent pieces of meat. You’ll notice the difference immediately.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the rice cooks, wash and dry the fresh produce. Cut out and discard the cabbage core; thinly slice the leaves. Cut off and discard the root ends of the scallions; thinly slice the scallions on an angle, separating the white bottoms and green tops.

stories.title: How To: Chop Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, or green onions, are one of our favorite aromatic vegetables. There are two parts of the vegetable: the white bottom and the green top. They're used a little differently in cooking—the white bottoms are similar in use to regular onions and are usually cooked; the green tops are often used raw as a garnish. In our recipes, we specify to separate them. Check out this video to see how we do it.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the kimchi marinates, pat the steaks dry with paper towels; season with salt and pepper on both sides. In a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned steaks and cook 2 to 4 minutes per side for medium-rare, or until browned and cooked to your desired degree of doneness. Transfer to a cutting board, leaving any browned bits (or fond) in the pan. Let the cooked steaks rest for at least 5 minutes.

stories.title: How To: Prep a Steak for Browning
stories.description: Browning meat creates and develops flavor, taking your dish to the next level. There's a simple trick to browning steaks (or any other protein for that matter). Check out this video to see what it is.

recipe_steps.step_text: In a small pot, combine the rice, a big pinch of salt and 1 cup of water; heat to boiling on high. Once boiling, cover and reduce the heat to low. Simmer 12 to 14 minutes, or until the water has been absorbed and the rice is tender. Remove from heat and fluff the cooked rice with a fork.

recipe.title: Chicken Fried Chicken with Baked Sweet Potato & Collard Greens
recipe.sub_title: with Baked Sweet Potato & Collard Greens
recipe.description: You read it right, chefs—tonight’s dinner is chicken fried chicken, or chicken prepared with a bit of Southern flair. The technique of “chicken frying” traditionally applies to steak: the meat is coated and fried to achieve the crunchy, savory exterior characteristic of fried chicken (which is typically bone-in). But any boneless cut of meat can be chicken-fried—including chicken. We’re serving ours with baked sweet potato, dolloped with a tangy scallion-yogurt sauce, and a quick sauté of collard greens.

stories.title: Greek Yogurt
stories.description: Greek yogurt is yogurt that has been strained to remove the liquid whey, leaving a thicker, creamier texture as well as a higher protein content than regular yogurt. It’s been enjoyed in Eastern Europe, North Africa and Asia for centuries. Thanks to its thickness, it’s excellent in cooking, especially as the base of cooling yogurt sauces, as a marinade or as a substitute for buttermilk or heavy cream.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, an onion relative, belong to a class of plants with undeveloped root bulbs and long, hollow leaves. They're milder than most other onion plants and delicious both cooked and raw. (In our recipes, you'll typically cook the white bottoms and use the green tops as garnish, reflecting the difference in their potency.) Scallions are a wonderful addition to everything from scrambled eggs to soups to stir-fries.

stories.title: Collard Greens
stories.description: A staple in Southern cuisine, collard greens are a type of cabbage that, rather than forming a “head” like traditional cabbage, grows loosely at the top of a tall stem. Their delicious, mildly bitter taste is often described as a cross between cabbage and kale. In 2011, collard greens became the official state vegetable of South Carolina, formally cementing their presence in the culture and cooking of the South.

stories.title: Sweet Potato
stories.description: Despite its name, the sweet potato is not related to the group vegetables we know as “potatoes”—rather, the sweet potato is actually a member of the morning glory family. Columbus brought the tropical root crop, native to the Americas, back to Europe after his 1492 trip to the New World. It was eagerly adopted by Europeans and given the title of “potato” (from its indigenous Taino name, “batata”). Years later, in 1537, when the white potato first arrived in Europe, locals began referring to both vegetables as “potatoes,” creating a confusion that persists today. It wasn’t until the 1740s that American colonists developed the term “sweet potato” to distinguish the delicious tuber from its white counterpart.

stories.title: Red Wine Vinegar
stories.description: Like all wine vinegars, red wine vinegar is created by allowing wine to ferment, leading to the development of acetic acid. It is then aged for up to two years to mute its potent flavor. Thanks to its pleasant mellowness, red wine vinegar is a favorite for dressings and pickles. No matter how it’s used, it’s beloved for its vibrant color and subtly fruity taste.

stories.title: All-Purpose Flour
stories.description: The term “all-purpose flour” is used to describe wheat flour with a low to moderate protein content. All-purpose flour has less protein than bread flour (which more easily forms gluten to make dense, chewy bread), but more protein than airy cake or pastry flour. It can be used in a wide variety of applications and is considered an essential pantry ingredient for bakers and chefs alike.

ingredients.description: Chicken Fried Chicken Spice Blend (Sweet Paprika, Garlic Powder, Ground Black Pepper, Dried Oregano & Ground Cayenne Pepper)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 2 Teaspoons Chicken Fried Chicken Spice Blend (Sweet Paprika, Garlic Powder, Ground Black Pepper, Dried Oregano & Ground Cayenne Pepper)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Teaspoons Chicken Fried Chicken Spice Blend (Sweet Paprika, Garlic Powder, Ground Black Pepper, Dried Oregano & Ground Cayenne Pepper)

stories.title: Chicken Fried Chicken Spice Blend
stories.description:
In this recipe, we’re breading our chicken with flour and this robust spice blend to ensure that each bite is packed with flavor. Sweet paprika, garlic powder, black pepper and oregano add smoky, aromatic notes while a dash of cayenne pepper brings the perfect gentle kick of heat.

4 Parts Sweet Paprika

4 Parts Garlic Powder

4 Parts Ground Black Pepper

4 Parts Dried Oregano

1 Part Ground Cayenne Pepper

recipe_steps.step_text: Place the sweet potato on a sheet pan. Drizzle with olive oil and season with salt and pepper; turn to thoroughly coat. Arrange the seasoned sweet potato cut sides down. Add 2 tablespoons of water to the sheet pan; tightly cover the sheet pan with aluminum foil. Bake 28 to 30 minutes, or until the sweet potato is browned and tender when pierced with a fork. Remove from the oven.
Once the sweet potato has roasted for about 5 minutes, in a bowl, combine the white bottoms of the scallions, remaining yogurt and remaining vinegar; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Halve the sweet potato lengthwise. Cut off and discard the root ends of the scallions; thinly slice the scallions, separating the white bottoms and green tops. Remove and discard the collard green stems; thinly slice the leaves. Peel and mince the garlic. In a medium bowl, combine half the yogurt, half the vinegar and ¼ cup of water; season with salt and pepper.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

stories.title: How To: Chop Scallions
stories.description: Scallions, or green onions, are one of our favorite aromatic vegetables. There are two parts of the vegetable: the white bottom and the green top. They're used a little differently in cooking—the white bottoms are similar in use to regular onions and are usually cooked; the green tops are often used raw as a garnish. In our recipes, we specify to separate them. Check out this video to see how we do it.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the sweet potato continues to roast, in a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the collard greens and garlic; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the collard greens have wilted; season with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to a bowl and set aside in a warm place. Wipe out the pan.

While the sweet potato continues to roast, in a medium bowl, combine the flour and spice blend; season with salt and pepper. Pat the chicken dry with paper towels; season with salt and pepper on both sides. Working 1 piece at a time, coat both sides of the seasoned chicken in the flour-spice blend mixture (tapping off any excess), then in the yogurt-vinegar mixture (letting the excess drip off), then again in the flour-spice blend mixture.

While the sweet potato continues to roast, in the pan used to cook the collard greens, heat a thin layer of oil on medium-high until hot. Once the oil is hot enough that a drop of the coating sizzles immediately when added to the pan, add the coated chicken and cook 3 to 5 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate; immediately season with salt and pepper. Divide the cooked chicken, baked sweet potato and cooked collard greens between 2 plates. Top the sweet potato with a few spoonfuls of the scallion-yogurt sauce. Garnish with the green tops of the scallions. Enjoy!

stories.title: How To: Pan-Fry Chicken
stories.description: This essential technique yields perfectly-cooked chicken with a delicious, crispy skin. The process is incredibly easy. Check out this short video to see how it's done!

recipe.title: Shrimp Po' Boy Sandwiches with Romaine & Radish Salad
recipe.description: The “po’ boy” sandwich is a Louisiana specialty that can be made with a range of fillings, such as plump shrimp (especially common near the Gulf). In this recipe, we’re filling our oven-roasted rolls with sautéed shrimp, seasoned with an assortment of classic spices—including our signature Cajun blend. Topped with a zesty, creamy remoulade (a condiment similar to tartar sauce popular in Cajun cuisine) and served with a crisp side salad, these sandwiches make for quick, easy and incredibly satisfying Southern fare.

stories.title: Mayonnaise
stories.description: This thick, creamy sauce is the result of a unique process known as emulsion—or a blend of two liquids wherein one forms tiny droplets that are suspended in the other. In the case of traditional mayonnaise, oil droplets are evenly dispersed in a mixture of egg yolk, water and lemon juice or vinegar. By slowly whisking the oil into the base of egg yolk, water and acid, it breaks into small droplets, thickening the mixture and creating mayonnaise’s signature consistency. Although frequently used as a condiment, mayonnaise also makes an excellent ingredient in dressings, and it’s a favorite to lock in moisture when breading meat or poultry.

stories.title: Radish
stories.description: The root of a plant in the mustard family, (it’s name comes from the Latin “radix”, meaning root), the radish has been eaten since prehistoric times. It comes in a variety of shapes and colors, with flavors ranging from mild to peppery, and has a crispy, crunchy texture. It was brought to the United States by Spanish and Portuguese colonists—today, Florida is a major grower of radishes. It’s a favorite in salads, where it’s typically enjoyed raw.

stories.title: Whole Grain Mustard
stories.description: Made from the seeds of the mustard plant, this ubiquitous condiment is also, historically, one of the oldest. Recipes for sauces resembling the mustard we recognize today date as far back as the 4th Century, when they were used to glaze wild boar. And though we don't have any plans to put boar on the menu, mustard goes well with just about anything. The word itself is derived from two Latin words. "Must" comes from the Latin "mustum," the first juice pressed from wine grapes. The "-ard" comes from "ardens," meaning fiery or hot. The first mustards were a simple combination of "must" and ground mustard seeds, infusing the juice with the signature, slightly spicy flavor. The whole grain mustard we use is a combination of whole yellow and brown mustard seeds, blended with white wine and vinegar.

stories.title: Sweet Pickle Relish
stories.description: This favored condiment is made of cucumbers that have been pickled in sugar, vinegar and salt. Although relishes are made in many global cuisines, sweet pickle relish is considered a uniquely American classic. After it was introduced commercially to the American market in the late 1800s, it was quickly adopted as a favored topping for meats and sandwiches, as well as an easy way to enhance the flavors of potato salads or remoulades.

stories.title: Red Wine Vinegar
stories.description: Like all wine vinegars, red wine vinegar is created by allowing wine to ferment, leading to the development of acetic acid. It is then aged for up to two years to mute its potent flavor. Thanks to its pleasant mellowness, red wine vinegar is a favorite for dressings and pickles. No matter how it’s used, it’s beloved for its vibrant color and subtly fruity taste.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the rolls toast, in a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned shrimp and cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until opaque and cooked through. Remove from heat.

Line each toasted roll with 1 of the whole lettuce leaves. Spoon some of the remoulade sauce onto each lettuce leaf. Divide the cooked shrimp between the rolls; top with any remaining remoulade sauce, if you’d like.

Just before serving, in a large bowl, combine the radishes and chopped lettuce leaves. Add enough of the vinaigrette to coat the salad (you may have extra); toss to combine and season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the sandwiches between 2 plates. Serve with the salad on the side. Enjoy!

recipe_steps.step_text: Place the rolls on a sheet pan, cut sides up. Toast in the oven 3 to 5 minutes, or until lightly browned. Remove from the oven and transfer to a clean, dry work surface.

In a medium bowl, combine the mayonnaise, sweet pickle relish and â…” of the mustard; season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside. In a small bowl, combine the vinegar and remaining mustard; season with salt and pepper to taste. Slowly whisk in 2 tablespoons of olive oil until well combined.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How to Build Any Vinaigrette
stories.description: With dressings, as with most things, we believe simpler is better! There are three basic components of a vinaigrette: a base, some kind of seasoning and oil. As the name suggests, the base of a vinaigrette is commonly vinegar, but any other acidic ingredient will work just as well (we love using fresh lemon juice). Next: the seasoning. In many of our recipes, we use salt and pepper. It's important to season the base before adding the oil. Salt is water soluble and will dissolve well into vinegar or lemon juice. (It won't dissolve into oil.) From there, all you have to do is add the oil. Add it in a slow, steady stream and whisk constantly to emulsify (or incorporate) the vinaigrette. Simply add it to the salad and toss to coat.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 425°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Slice the rolls lengthwise, keeping them intact (they should look like hot dog buns). Cut off and discard the root end of the lettuce; set 2 large leaves aside and roughly chop the remaining leaves. Cut off and discard the stem ends of the radishes; very thinly slice the radishes into rounds. Pat the shrimp dry with paper towels and place in a bowl. Season the shrimp with salt, pepper and the spice blend; toss to coat.

stories.title: Red Wine Vinegar
stories.description: Like all wine vinegars, red wine vinegar is created by allowing wine to ferment, leading to the development of acetic acid. It is then aged for up to two years to mute its potent flavor. Thanks to its pleasant mellowness, red wine vinegar is a favorite for dressings and pickles. No matter how it’s used, it’s beloved for its vibrant color and subtly fruity taste.

stories.title: Radish
stories.description: The root of a plant in the mustard family, (it’s name comes from the Latin “radix”, meaning root), the radish has been eaten since prehistoric times. It comes in a variety of shapes and colors, with flavors ranging from mild to peppery, and has a crispy, crunchy texture. It was brought to the United States by Spanish and Portuguese colonists—today, Florida is a major grower of radishes. It’s a favorite in salads, where it’s typically enjoyed raw.

stories.title: Whole Grain Mustard
stories.description: Made from the seeds of the mustard plant, this ubiquitous condiment is also, historically, one of the oldest. Recipes for sauces resembling the mustard we recognize today date as far back as the 4th Century, when they were used to glaze wild boar. And though we don't have any plans to put boar on the menu, mustard goes well with just about anything. The word itself is derived from two Latin words. "Must" comes from the Latin "mustum," the first juice pressed from wine grapes. The "-ard" comes from "ardens," meaning fiery or hot. The first mustards were a simple combination of "must" and ground mustard seeds, infusing the juice with the signature, slightly spicy flavor. The whole grain mustard we use is a combination of whole yellow and brown mustard seeds, blended with white wine and vinegar.

(It won't dissolve into oil.) From there, all you have to do is add the oil. Add it in a slow, steady stream and whisk constantly to emulsify (or incorporate) the vinaigrette. Simply add it to the salad and toss to coat.

stories.title: Mayonnaise
stories.description: This thick, creamy sauce is the result of a unique process known as emulsion—or a blend of two liquids wherein one forms tiny droplets that are suspended in the other. In the case of traditional mayonnaise, oil droplets are evenly dispersed in a mixture of egg yolk, water and lemon juice or vinegar. By slowly whisking the oil into the base of egg yolk, water and acid, it breaks into small droplets, thickening the mixture and creating mayonnaise’s signature consistency. Although frequently used as a condiment, mayonnaise also makes an excellent ingredient in dressings, and it’s a favorite to lock in moisture when breading meat or poultry.

stories.title: Sweet Pickle Relish
stories.description: This favored condiment is made of cucumbers that have been pickled in sugar, vinegar and salt. Although relishes are made in many global cuisines, sweet pickle relish is considered a uniquely American classic. After it was introduced commercially to the American market in the late 1800s, it was quickly adopted as a favored topping for meats and sandwiches, as well as an easy way to enhance the flavors of potato salads or remoulades.

We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe.title: Orecchiette Pasta & Roasted Chickpeas with Kale & Smoked Paprika
recipe.description: Here, pasta with chickpeas—or “pasta e ceci,” as the beloved dish is known in Italian—gets a delicious update. We’re using orecchiette, whose shape is just right for holding onto other ingredients. And for delightful texture, we’re roasting our chickpeas, turning them crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside, before tossing them with smoked paprika. (Be sure to dry your chickpeas as thoroughly as possible to ensure the perfect crisp!) Sautéed kale, briny capers and a lemon-butter sauce add plenty of brightness.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Curly Kale
stories.description: With its crinkly, frilly leaves, curly kale is almost as beautiful to look at as it is delicious to eat. It’s grown mainly for autumn and winter harvests, as the cool weather actually enhances the kale's inherent sweetness. Although many of our recipes call for the fibrous center rib of the kale to be removed before the leafy green is used, the rib is actually fully edible. When chopped up finely, it makes an excellent addition to soups and stocks!

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

recipe_steps.step_text: While the chickpeas continue to roast, add the pasta to the pot of boiling of water and cook 9 to 11 minutes, or until al dente (still slightly firm to the bite). Reserving ½ cup of the pasta cooking water, drain thoroughly.

stories.title: How to Make Sure Your Pasta is Al Dente
stories.description:
Nothing beats perfectly cooked, al dente pasta. But how do you know if it's done? There are numerous ways to test the doneness of your noodles when they’re cooking. Some folk wisdom says to throw a piece of pasta against the wall; if it sticks, it's done. As much fun as we had experimenting with this method, we found the best way to test the pasta was, shockingly, by tasting it. In Italian, "al dente" means "to the tooth," meaning that it's still slightly firm to the bite. As your pasta cooks, periodically (and carefully) taste a piece of it. If it's still too firm, let it cook a little longer.

In some of our recipes, we specify to remove the pasta from the pot when it's "just shy of al dente." This is because, later, the pasta will be cooked in a sauce. Removing the pasta from the water just before it's al dente will ensure that the final product isn't overcooked.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 450°F. Line a sheet pan with a layer of paper towels. Drain and rinse the chickpeas; spread onto the paper towel-lined sheet pan. Using a second layer of paper towels, gently pat or roll the chickpeas to thoroughly dry; discard the paper towels and any loose chickpea skins. Drizzle with olive oil and season with salt and pepper; toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer and roast, stirring halfway through, 24 to 26 minutes, or until golden brown and crispy. Remove from the oven and add the smoked paprika; carefully toss to coat.

While the chickpeas continue to roast, to the pan of kale, add the cooked pasta, capers, butter, the juice of 2 lemon wedges and half the reserved pasta cooking water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 2 to 4 minutes, or until thoroughly combined. (If the sauce seems dry, gradually add the remaining pasta cooking water to achieve your desired consistency.) Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste.
recipe_steps.step_title: Add the pasta & make the sauce:

recipe_steps.step_text: Off the heat, add the roasted chickpeas to the pan. Stir to thoroughly combine; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the finished pasta between 2 dishes. Garnish with the cheese. Serve with the remaining lemon wedges on the side, if you’d like. Enjoy!

While the pasta cooks, in a large pan, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the onion and garlic; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 5 to 7 minutes, or until softened. Add the kale and ¼ cup of water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until the kale has wilted and the liquid has cooked off.

While the chickpeas roast, wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Peel and small dice the onion. Peel and mince the garlic. Remove and discard the kale stems; roughly chop the leaves. Roughly chop the capers. Quarter and deseed the lemon.

stories.title: Chickpeas
stories.description: These delicious legumes have been cultivated for at least 9,000 years. Today, they are popular around the world, especially in Indian and Middle Eastern cuisines. Kabuli chickpeas, larger and lighter than most other varieties, are the most common type sold in the U.S. Known as garbanzo beans in Spanish-speaking regions, they have a creamy texture and mildly nutty flavor. Chickpeas are the primary ingredient in hummus—a Middle Eastern paste also made with tahini—but are also widely enjoyed roasted, baked or boiled.

stories.title: Smoked Paprika
stories.description: Smoked paprika is an excellent way to add depth of flavor to an array of dishes. Though it's most often associated with Hungarian cuisine (some say that Hungary still produces the finest paprika), the peppers used to make it are American natives. Colonialism brought the peppers back to Spain, and from there they spread the world over. Smoked paprika is made from sweet red peppers, which are then air-dried, smoked and ground to a fine, bright red powder.

stories.title: Orecchiette Pasta
stories.description: Literally translated to “little ears” from Italian, diminutive orecchiette pasta likely hails from Southern Italy’s Puglia region. It’s often served with vegetable-based sauces—possibly because its cup-like form helps it scoop up small veggies or chunky sauces. Thanks to its unique shape, it has a delicious flavor and texture, which is thinner in the center than along the edges, making for the perfect combination of soft and chewy.

stories.title: How To: Small Dice an Onion

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: Butter
stories.description: What would cooking be without butter? Butter is so essential to so many cuisines and dishes across the world that its absence seems almost unimaginable. Millennia ago, butter was made from goat or sheep's milk (before the domestication of cattle). In Northern Europe, cooler climates made it easier to store butter for longer periods of time. But even in the warm climates of the eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East and India, butter was used and treasured for its rich, exquisite taste (often in the form of ghee, or other clarified butter preparations). From sautéing and frying to baking and sauce-making, butter has been used in countless ways.

stories.title: Capers
stories.description: Capers, a traditional ingredient in Mediterranean cuisines, are actually tiny flower buds. They’re plucked before the plant (the caper bush, or Flinders rose) can blossom, when they're a dark olive green. After harvesting, the bud is pickled and kept in either salt or a salt-vinegar mixture. During this process, the capers release mustard oil, giving them a distinct, savory flavor.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

recipe.title: Cheesy Enchiladas Rojas with Mixed Mushrooms & Spinach
recipe.description: Enchiladas are a time-honored favorite in Mexican and Tex-Mex cuisines. After all, what’s not to love about tortillas wrapped around a hearty filling of vegetables, spices and more—then smothered with sauce and cheese? For distinctive flavor, we’re making these enchiladas rojas (or enchiladas in red sauce) with three kinds of sautéed mushrooms: round-capped cremini, and ruffled maitake and oyster. Mild Monterey Jack melts down perfectly in the oven, topping off the dish with layers of satisfying texture.

stories.title: Flour Tortillas
stories.description: While corn tortillas were a staple of the Ancient Aztecs' diet for millennia, flour tortillas (made from wheat flour) first appeared only a few hundred years ago. They were created by the Spaniards, who began planting wheat crops in the New World in the 16th Century. Wheat grew particularly well in the colder climates of Northern Mexico, and today, flour tortillas are a favorite in Northern Mexican and Tex-Mex cuisines. They're celebrated for their pliancy, soft texture and mild, clean flavor.

stories.title: Long Grain White Rice
stories.description: With less starch than shorter varieties of rice, versatile long grain rice is beloved for its fluffy texture. When cooked, the grains stay separate (rather than clumping together like those of starchier, shorter-grained rices), which makes the rice ideal when served on its own as a simple side dish, or used in pilafs. Long grain white rice is celebrated for its pleasantly chewy texture and mild, buttery flavor.

stories.title: Spinach
stories.description: A member of the beet family, spinach likely originated in Persia, where it was cultivated as early as the 4th Century. Over the next several centuries, it made its way to Europe and Eastern Asia. It grows fast, and has a prized, tender texture, stunning green color and subtly sweet flavor. In fact, in the Middle Ages, spinach was often used as an ingredient in sweet dishes and desserts.

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: Mexican Spice Blend
stories.description:
With just a few ingredients, this spice blend achieves authentic, robust flavor. We're using piquant garlic powder, mild ancho chile powder, sweet paprika, ground cumin and fragrant Mexican oregano to achieve the deliciously earthy, herby and zesty flavors Mexican cuisines is so well known for.

Equal Parts:

Garlic Powder

Ancho Chile Powder

Sweet Paprika

Ground Cumin

Whole Mexican Oregano

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 475°F. In a large pot, combine the rice, a big pinch of salt and 1 cup of water; heat to boiling on high. Once boiling, cover and reduce the heat to low. Simmer 12 to 14 minutes, or until the water has been absorbed and the rice is tender. Remove from heat and fluff the cooked rice with a fork.

In the pan used to cook the spinach, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, 4 to 6 minutes, or until browned and crispy. Add half the spice blend and cook, stirring occasionally, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant; season with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to the pot of cooked rice and spinach. Wipe out the pan.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the rice cooks, wash and dry the fresh produce. Thinly slice the cremini mushrooms; using your hands, tear the maitake and oyster mushrooms into bite-sized pieces. Peel and small dice the onion. Peel and mince the garlic. Quarter the lime. Grate the cheese. Roughly chop the cilantro leaves and stems.

stories.title: How To: Small Dice an Onion
stories.description: Small dice an onion? No sweat (but maybe a few tears). Check out this video to see exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Chop Herbs
stories.description: Our chefs' technique for chopping herbs is actually more like slicing, which keeps your herbs looking great and won't stain your cutting board. Find out how it's done in the video!

recipe_steps.step_text: While the rice continues to cook, in a large pan, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the spinach; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until wilted. Transfer to a strainer; hold or rest over a bowl. Using a spoon, press down on the cooked spinach to release as much liquid as possible; discard the liquid. Transfer to a cutting board and roughly chop. Transfer to the pot of cooked rice. Wipe out the pan.

Place the tortillas on a clean, dry work surface. Evenly spread about ¾ cup of the filling into the bottom of a baking dish. Divide the remaining filling between the centers of the tortillas; tightly roll up each tortilla around the filling. Carefully transfer the rolled tortillas to the baking dish, seam sides down, in a single layer. Evenly top with the remaining sauce and remaining cheese. Bake 12 to 14 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and lightly browned. Remove from the oven and let stand for at least 2 minutes before serving. Garnish with the remaining cilantro. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Finish the enchiladas & serve your dish:

recipe_steps.step_text: In the pan used to brown the mushrooms, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the onion, garlic and remaining spice blend; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until softened and fragrant. Add the tomato sauce; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 3 to 5 minutes, or until slightly thickened; season with salt and pepper to taste. Remove from heat. To the pot of cooked rice and vegetables, add the juice of all 4 lime wedges, half the cheese, half the sauce and all but a pinch of the cilantro. Stir to thoroughly combine; season with salt and pepper to taste.
recipe_steps.step_title: Make the sauce & finish the filling:

stories.title: Mixed Mushrooms (Maitake, Cremini, Oyster)
stories.description: For this recipe, we’ve using three of our favorite mushroom varieties together. Flavorful, ruffle-capped maitakes (also known as “hen of the woods” mushrooms) are the perfect complement to pleasantly mild, button-topped creminis. We’re rounding out the trio with fan-shaped oysters, both delicately sweet and meaty. Combined, they add a burst of rich and savory umami flavor.

stories.title: Flour Tortillas
stories.description: While corn tortillas were a staple of the Ancient Aztecs' diet for millennia, flour tortillas (made from wheat flour) first appeared only a few hundred years ago. They were created by the Spaniards, who began planting wheat crops in the New World in the 16th Century. Wheat grew particularly well in the colder climates of Northern Mexico, and today, flour tortillas are a favorite in Northern Mexican and Tex-Mex cuisines. They're celebrated for their pliancy, soft texture and mild, clean flavor.

stories.title: Monterey Jack Cheese
stories.description: There’s some controversy surrounding the origins of mild, buttery Monterey Jack Cheese. Some believe it was invented by cheese maker David Jacks in Monterey, California in the late 19th Century, while others argue it’s most likely derived from a recipe for queso del país (“country cheese”) brought to California by Franciscan monks a hundred years earlier. Regardless, the delicious semisoft cow’s milk cheese is now considered a uniquely American product, and can come plain or with added flavorings like chile peppers, garlic or herbs.

stories.title: Mexican Spice Blend
stories.description:
With just a few ingredients, this spice blend achieves authentic, robust flavor. We're using piquant garlic powder, mild ancho chile powder, sweet paprika, ground cumin and fragrant Mexican oregano to achieve the deliciously earthy, herby and zesty flavors Mexican cuisines is so well known for.

Equal Parts:

Garlic Powder

Ancho Chile Powder

Sweet Paprika

Ground Cumin

Whole Mexican Oregano

stories.title: How To: Chop Herbs
stories.description: Our chefs' technique for chopping herbs is actually more like slicing, which keeps your herbs looking great and won't stain your cutting board. Find out how it's done in the video!

stories.title: Long Grain White Rice
stories.description: With less starch than shorter varieties of rice, versatile long grain rice is beloved for its fluffy texture. When cooked, the grains stay separate (rather than clumping together like those of starchier, shorter-grained rices), which makes the rice ideal when served on its own as a simple side dish, or used in pilafs. Long grain white rice is celebrated for its pleasantly chewy texture and mild, buttery flavor.

stories.title: Tomato Sauce
stories.description: Delicious and versatile, the tomato is particularly well-suited to the canning process. It’s available canned or jarred in nearly every form—as concentrated tomato paste, crushed, whole or diced. Tomato sauce, generally made from fresh tomatoes that have been cooked down, is one of the most popular ways to preserve this cherished summer fruit. It provides an easy and delicious starting point for a quick pasta sauce, pizza topping or calzone filling.

stories.title: Spinach
stories.description: A member of the beet family, spinach likely originated in Persia, where it was cultivated as early as the 4th Century. Over the next several centuries, it made its way to Europe and Eastern Asia. It grows fast, and has a prized, tender texture, stunning green color and subtly sweet flavor. In fact, in the Middle Ages, spinach was often used as an ingredient in sweet dishes and desserts.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: Lime
stories.description: One of the most acidic citrus fruits, limes likely originated in Southeast Asia. There are several types of limes, but the variety most commonly enjoyed in the U.S. is the Persian lime, known for its plump, seedless flesh and dark green skin. If allowed to ripen to maturity, limes actually turn yellow, but they're harvested when green for superior flavor (and to avoid confusion with lemons!).

stories.title: Cilantro
stories.description: Cilantro is one of the most refreshing herbs. It's unbelievably tasty and a perfect, herbaceous complement to all kinds of other flavors. Cilantro and the spice coriander actually come from the same plant. Coriander is the seeds, whereas cilantro is the long, leafy shoots that grow from them.

stories.title: How To: Small Dice an Onion
stories.description: Small dice an onion? No sweat (but maybe a few tears). Check out this video to see exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe.title: Roasted Cauliflower MeuniÃ¨re with Soft-Boiled Eggs & Parmesan Breadcrumbs
recipe.description: Meunière—at its most basic, a sauce of browned butter, lemon juice and parsley—originated in France. From there, it made its way to the American South, where it’s now essential to Creole cuisine. In this unique recipe, we’re using the velvety sauce to dress roasted cauliflower, served with sautéed kale and soft-boiled eggs. A sprinkling of lightly cheesy, pan-toasted breadcrumbs completes this gourmet meal.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Butter
stories.description: What would cooking be without butter? Butter is so essential to so many cuisines and dishes across the world that its absence seems almost unimaginable. Millennia ago, butter was made from goat or sheep's milk (before the domestication of cattle). In Northern Europe, cooler climates made it easier to store butter for longer periods of time. But even in the warm climates of the eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East and India, butter was used and treasured for its rich, exquisite taste (often in the form of ghee, or other clarified butter preparations). From sautéing and frying to baking and sauce-making, butter has been used in countless ways.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the cauliflower continues to roast, carefully add the eggs to the pot of boiling water. Cook for exactly 7 minutes. Drain thoroughly and rinse under cold water for 30 seconds to 1 minute to stop the cooking process. When cool enough to handle, carefully peel the cooked eggs and set aside in a warm place.

While the cauliflower roasts, in a medium pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the breadcrumbs; season with salt and pepper. Toast, stirring frequently, 2 to 4 minutes, or until golden brown. Remove from heat and add the cheese; stir until well combined. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate. Wipe out the pan.

While the eggs cook, in the pan used to make the Parmesan breadcrumbs, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the shallot and garlic; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, 1 to 2 minutes, or until softened and fragrant. Add the kale and ¼ cup of water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 5 to 7 minutes, or until the kale has wilted and the water has cooked off. Stir in the lemon zest; season with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to a plate. Wipe out the pan.

Place the cauliflower on a sheet pan. Drizzle with olive oil and season with salt and pepper; toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer and roast, stirring halfway through, 18 to 20 minutes, or until browned and tender when pierced with a fork. Remove from the oven.

In the same pan, heat the butter on medium-high until melted. Cook, stirring occasionally, 15 to 30 seconds, or until the butter foams. Once the foam subsides, continue cooking, occasionally swirling the pan, 2 to 3 minutes, or until deep golden brown and nuttily fragrant. Turn off the heat. Stir in the parsley, capers and the juice of all 4 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the roasted cauliflower, cooked kale, Parmesan breadcrumbs and cooked eggs between 2 plates; season with salt and pepper. Top with a few spoonfuls of the sauce. Enjoy!

stories.title: How To: Brown Butter
stories.description: What could be better than butter? Brown butter! This simple process toasts the milk solids in the butter, giving it a complex, rich flavor and a distinctly nutty aroma. Watch this video to see exactly what the process looks like.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a small pot of salted water to boiling on high. Cut out and discard the cauliflower core; cut the head into small florets. Peel and thinly slice the shallot and garlic. Remove and discard the kale stems; keep the leaves whole. Using a peeler, remove the rind of the lemon, avoiding the pith; mince to get 2 teaspoons of zest (or use a zester). Quarter and deseed the lemon. Roughly chop the capers. Pick the parsley leaves off the stems; discard the stems and thinly slice the leaves.

stories.title: How To: Prep Cauliflower Florets
stories.description: Cauliflower is one of our favorite cool-weather vegetables. In certain recipes, we specify to cut the head into small florets. Check out this short video to learn the simple technique that will make prepping cauliflower a snap!

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

stories.title: How To: Get Perfect Citrus Zest
stories.description: Zest is one of the best ways to brighten up a dish. It translates the essential oils of the citrus into flavor for all kinds of meals. See how it's done here!

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Peel Garlic
stories.description: If you're cooking with us, you're using garlic in virtually every recipe. Don't waste any more time trying to peel it! Check out the video for a quick tip.

stories.title: How To: Separate Leafy Greens from the Stems
stories.description: Check out this simple trick for separating the stems and leaves of one of our favorite ingredients: kale. You won't even need a knife!

stories.title: How To: Prep Herbs Really Fast
stories.description: It’s time to prep some herbs! In this video, we’re continuing our quest to help you cut down prep time in the kitchen. Today, we’ve got herbs on the butcher block. Fresh herbs give incredible flavor to whatever you’re cooking. We turned to our chef to see how to get all our herbs off the stem and chopped up neatly in as little time as possible.

stories.title: White Cauliflower
stories.description: A cauliflower is actually a member of the cabbage family whose flowers don’t grow past the bud stage, resulting in the plant’s familiar dense florets. To preserve the striking white color of the cauliflower, farmers will often pull its large leaves over its head and tie them together, covering the cauliflower like a hat—and keeping the head from being exposed to direct sunlight.

stories.title: Lacinato Kale
stories.description: Lacinato kale, a native Tuscan variety, is a gorgeous, deep blue-green variety. Its highly embossed leaves give it a somewhat "prehistoric" look, so much so that it has been given the nickname "dinosaur kale." Whatever you call it, it's packed with collosal amounts of nutrients and flavor.

stories.title: How To: Get Perfect Citrus Zest
stories.description: Zest is one of the best ways to brighten up a dish. It translates the essential oils of the citrus into flavor for all kinds of meals. See how it's done here!

stories.title: How To: Brown Butter
stories.description: What could be better than butter? Brown butter! This simple process toasts the milk solids in the butter, giving it a complex, rich flavor and a distinctly nutty aroma. Watch this video to see exactly what the process looks like.

stories.title: Capers
stories.description: Capers, a traditional ingredient in Mediterranean cuisines, are actually tiny flower buds. They’re plucked before the plant (the caper bush, or Flinders rose) can blossom, when they're a dark olive green. After harvesting, the bud is pickled and kept in either salt or a salt-vinegar mixture. During this process, the capers release mustard oil, giving them a distinct, savory flavor.

stories.title: Panko Breadcrumbs
stories.description: What makes panko so special? As strange as it may seem, panko isn’t baked… it’s electrocuted. The dough is allowed to rise naturally, then it’s placed between metal plates. High voltages are passed through the bread, cooking it. The electrocuted bread has distinct advantages. Essentially, it has no crust and is dried throughout. This means that even after they've been cooked (again, in this recipe), the breadcrumbs will be crunchy, light and airy.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

stories.title: How To: Prep Cauliflower Florets
stories.description: Cauliflower is one of our favorite cool-weather vegetables. In certain recipes, we specify to cut the head into small florets. Check out this short video to learn the simple technique that will make prepping cauliflower a snap!

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Parsley
stories.description: Parsley is one of the most common ingredients in our recipes. Native to southeast Europe and west Asia, it has spread around the world and become indispensible to a number of regional cuisines. The name “parsley” comes from a Greek word meaning “rock celery.” As that name would suggest, the two are closely related, members of the Apiaceae family, along with carrots, fennel and parsnips. Its distinctive flavor is complemented by versatile green and woody notes, adding subtle flavor and enhancing the dishes its used to flavor.

stories.title: Butter
stories.description: What would cooking be without butter? Butter is so essential to so many cuisines and dishes across the world that its absence seems almost unimaginable. Millennia ago, butter was made from goat or sheep's milk (before the domestication of cattle). In Northern Europe, cooler climates made it easier to store butter for longer periods of time. But even in the warm climates of the eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East and India, butter was used and treasured for its rich, exquisite taste (often in the form of ghee, or other clarified butter preparations). From sautéing and frying to baking and sauce-making, butter has been used in countless ways.

stories.title: Shallot
stories.description: Shallots are an intensely flavorful bulb in the same family as garlic and leeks. Many of the vegetables in this family are considered aromatics. Garlic, shallots, leeks, onions and many other fragrant vegetables are called aromatics because of the amazing scents they produce during cooking. Almost every cuisine uses some combination of these vegetables as a base. Aromatics build flavor, providing structure and a subtle, well-rounded backdrop for the “stars” of your dish.
